Subject: Re: [neat] RE: Request for Comments: Geographical and Behavioural Space Considerations
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=464818732; y=EwprhrCF_Nqsl95zbznaZFNdn0kXIy58BGQxIn9Z6ubq0_pou5Ai

Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset=windows-1252

Hello all,

I think these are great ideas. In fact, I (with students and co=
llaborators) have been working on two different projects related to these i=
deas for a while now. I hope to have something to announce on these fronts =
in the near future. :-)


Best regards,
Jeff Clune

Assistant Professor
Com=
puter Science
University of Wyoming
jeffclune@...
jeffclune.com

On Au=
g 27, 2013, at 11:01 PM, <lehman.154@...> wrote:

> 
> Hi Colin,
> 
> 
=
> 
> I like the idea of exploring different mechanisms for encouraging dive=
rsity during search, and geography is an interesting structure that could b=
e used for such a purpose. I imagine what you are suggesting goes beyond th=
e typical idea of island models or other diversity mechanisms where the env=
ironment within each geographical niche is typically the same. 
> 
> 
> 
> =
That is, one of the most interesting things from an evolutionary perspectiv=
e about different geographical regions of the world is that what strategies=
 are adaptive changes between them. In other words, altitude and temperatur=
e and chemical composition vary with geography, which might correspondingly=
 vary the attractors for optimizing fitness. In this way, across all differ=
ent geographies you might encounter a wide range of cool strategies that ar=
e all locally well-adapted.
> 
> 
> 
> If I correctly recall an earlier dis=
cussion, you were at one point interested in different geographical niches =
where selection would vary among them, e.g. there would be some differences=
 between the environments within each niche. That way, the overall search m=
ight be more non-objective because it is not driven to any one super-organi=
sm but in finding interesting solutions within all of the different niches.=
 So I think there might be some interesting parallels between that kind of =
idea and novelty search with local competition or the behavioral diversity =
approach. However, your idea seems to extend upon how they've been previous=
ly applied.
> 
> 
> 
> In Ken and I's virtual creature paper, novelty was m=
easured in how different a virtual creature's morphology was from others in=
 the population, using a coarse small-dimensional space of morphologies (e.=
g. their height and mass). Competition (measured in how far the organisms c=
ould locomote) occurred locally between points near in that low-dimensional=
 morphology space. The idea was that NS+LC would discover a wide range of f=
unctional and yet divergent VCs.
> 
> 
> 
> However, instead of a morpholog=
y space where the underlying evaluation environment is uniform (e.g. the wo=
rld any creature is evaluated in is exactly the same), you could also have =
something like you are suggesting, where the evaluation environment varies =
over a space (e.g. some environments in one part of the geographic space co=
uld be hilly and others in a different area, flat). 
> 
> 
> 
> That is, yo=
u could have the space where novelty is measured in be an evolvable coordin=
ate that specifies its position within some overall 'geography', and that t=
he underlying environment shifts over this geography (I think this is what =
is novel about what you are suggesting). Of course, this artificial 'geogra=
phy' wouldn't have to align with how environments shift over terrestrial ge=
ography. For example, you could have a 2D geography where gravity varies ac=
ross one axis, and friction varies over the other. I'm not sure what kinds =
of critters would evolve in such a system, but probably you would find some=
 interesting things. For example, in low gravity/low friction, you might fi=
nd sliding high-jumpers, whereas in high gravity/high friction, you might f=
ind little rolling creatures. You could call it a geographical space, or ma=
ybe more generally, a space of niches.
> 
> 
> 
> What I'm getting at is th=
at there may be many different ways to implement the same underlying multio=
bjective concept. In other words, you are trying to encourage diversity in =
one or more axes and pressure to achieve in others. That is, you can use NS=
GA-II ala NS+LC or behavioral diversity (and replace behavioral or morpholo=
gical distance with geographical), or you could modify NEAT's speciation me=
chanism as you suggested, which also balances diversity and performance. 
>=
 
> 
> 
> One important thing to consider is whether you want competition t=
o be global (e.g. everyone competes on the same scale of fitness) or local =
(e.g. everyone competes purely relative to other organisms in their immedia=
te environment). It might be nice to have this be a setting within the syst=
em, because depending on your application you might want more or less "non-=
objectiveness," where local competition might bias towards more non-objecti=
veness and global competition might focus more on overall fitness optimizat=
ion.
> 
> 
> 
> In any case, I think this direction is very interesting fro=
m both a research and SharpNEAT perspective, and I look forward to see how =
your work enfolds. I hope my feedback is helpful, and not merely scattered.=

> 
> 
> 
> Best,
> 
> Joel
> 
> 
> 
> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, <martin=
.pyka@...> wrote:
> 
> Hi Colin,
> 
> your idea of implementing some kind o=
f location in a 2d space for each agent sounds interesting. 
> 
> Just to a=
ssure that I understand you correct: you are working with objective fitness=
 functions, not a co-evolution approach where a geo-location might also pla=
y an important role!?
> 
> You wrote, population density should adjust the =
fitness. This means, two species cannot share the same area (or don't you u=
se the concept of species)!?
> 
> Do you aim to model something in analogy =
to nature? Then, I don't get the link. In natural systems (which is based o=
n co-evolution and open-ended) the location on earth determines what is the=
 predator and what is the prey, and which environmental properties must be =
incorporated in the evolutionary development. In the simulation that you ai=
m to setup (if I understand you correctly), it seems that you would like to=
 use the geo-location to create more diversity for your objective search!?
=
> 
> Best,
> Martin
> 
> 
> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Colin Green <colin=
.green1@...> wrote:
> >
> > Hi all,
> > 
> > I'm starting to think about di=
rection for the next SharpNEAT
> > iteration. There's been a lot of talk re=
cently about novelty search
> > versus objective search, and maybe mixtures=
 of the two. I myself
> > talked about how in the natural world organisms a=
re separated in both
> > behavioural space (i.e. novel behaviour is less li=
kely to compete for
> > the same resources as existing behaviours) but also=
 geographical
> > space, and I think that geographical space is a key facto=
r that is
> > missing from NEAT based search currently, and possibly EC as =
a whole,
> > with the caveat there may be other research groups with work i=
n that
> > area that I'm unaware of.
> > 
> > My current plan is to focus o=
n this geographical space idea for this
> > iteration because it is the sim=
plest to implement. Dealing with
> > behavioural space is potentially more =
complicated because how to
> > compare behaviour varies across problem doma=
ins and how you identify
> > the key factors to compare is probably a non-t=
rivial problem. I want
> > to try and tackle this at some point, but I'm al=
so keen to explore the
> > geo-space idea.
> > 
> > What does this all mean=
 in practical terms?
> > 
> > SharpNEAT is a kit of parts that allows you t=
o swap in replacement
> > parts such as an alternative genetic representati=
on and/or associated
> > genetic operators (recombination, mutation, etc) w=
ith minimal impact
> > on other parts in the kit (in principle anyway). I'm=
 proposing to
> > provide an alternative evolution algorithm class that rep=
laces NEAT's
> > genome based speciation (which clusters genomes into K clu=
sters in
> > genetic space), with a geographical space alternative (I'll ca=
ll it
> > geo-space for short).
> > 
> > The idea is that we have some cart=
esian/euclidean space (probably a
> > square 2D space initially to keep the=
 code simple, but 3D or 'globe'
> > space (2-sphere) are reasonable alterna=
tives). The seed genomes are
> > each assigned a random coord in the geo-sp=
ace and this will be fixed
> > for the life of that genome. So we are basic=
ally adding a physical
> > attribute to the genome such that our population=
 members are probably
> > better referred to as organisms (or agents or pop=
ulation members).
> > I'll use 'agent' because it's easier to type :)
> > 
=
> > Agent fitness is now adjusted by population density at the agent's
> > =
geo-location, this allows really bad agents to survive so long as they
> > =
are in a sparse region of geo-space, thus allowing for some diversity
> > o=
f the genome pool.
> > 
> > Reproduction - I haven't put much thought into =
this but the two
> > options I see are to create offspring agents near to t=
heir parent(s)
> > versus randomly scattered. Probably some 'dispersion' va=
riable will
> > define the amount of scattering with 0 being atop of the pa=
rent (or
> > between the two?) and 1 being totally random. (Question: Is e.=
g. seed
> > scattering in nature gaussian?). Clearly if agent's are spawned=
 near
> > their parent's we would expect to see clusters of agent's with si=
milar
> > behaviour, and that clustering will increase population density a=
nd
> > therefore lower the fitness of agent's in that cluster. So there is =
a
> > form of fitness sharing going on, but as I say, I haven't really
> > =
thought through the implications and dynamics of that. But it would be
> > =
interesting to set up, play with and observe what happens.
> > 
> > Factori=
ng in behavioural space considerations should be possible at a
> > later da=
te, e.g. fitness at a geo-location is not adjusted down if an
> > agent has=
 novel behaviour compared to other agent's at that
> > geo-location.
> > 
>=
 > As per usual - any thoughts and feedback are welcome.
> > 
> > Colin
> >=

> 
> 


--Apple-Mail=_E19B6B5D-D0C4-47F9-BCB1-545B801EF718

iv><p>Hi Colin,</p><p><span style=3D"background-color:transparent;"><br></s=
pan></p><p style=3D"font-size: 13px; font-family: arial, helvetica, clean, =
sans-serif; background-color: transparent; font-style: normal; "><span styl=
e=3D"background-color:transparent;">I like the idea of exploring different =
mechanisms for encouraging diversity during search, and geography is an int=
eresting structure that could be used for such a purpose. I imagine what yo=
u are suggesting goes beyond the typical idea of island models or other div=
ersity mechanisms where the environment within each geographical niche is t=
ypically the same. </span></p><p style=3D"font-size: 13px; font-family=
: arial, helvetica, clean, sans-serif; background-color: transparent; font-=
style: normal; "><span style=3D"background-color:transparent;"><br></span><=
/p><p style=3D"font-size: 13px; font-family: arial, helvetica, clean, sans-=
serif; background-color: transparent; font-style: normal; "><span style=3D"=
background-color:transparent;">That is, one of the most interesting things =
from an evolutionary perspective about different geographical regions of th=
e world is that what strategies are adaptive changes between them. In other=
 words, altitude and temperature and chemical composition vary with geograp=
hy, which might correspondingly vary the attractors for optimizing fitness.=
 In this way, across all different geographies you might encounter a wide r=
ange of cool strategies that are all locally well-adapted.</span></p><p sty=
le=3D"font-size: 13px; font-family: arial, helvetica, clean, sans-serif; ba=
ckground-color: transparent; font-style: normal; "><span style=3D"backgroun=
d-color:transparent;"><br></span></p><p style=3D"font-size: 13px; font-fami=
ly: arial, helvetica, clean, sans-serif; background-color: transparent; fon=
t-style: normal; "><span style=3D"background-color:transparent;">If I corre=
ctly recall an earlier discussion, you were at one point interested in diff=
erent geographical niches where selection would vary among them, e.g. there=
 would be some differences between the environments within each niche. That=
 way, the overall search might be more non-objective because it is not driv=
en to any one super-organism but in finding interesting solutions within al=
l of the different niches. So I think there might be some interesting paral=
lels between that kind of idea and novelty search with local competition or=
 the behavioral diversity approach. However, your idea seems to extend upon=
 how they've been previously applied.</span></p><p style=3D"font-size: 13px=
; font-family: arial, helvetica, clean, sans-serif; background-color: trans=
parent; font-style: normal; "><span style=3D"background-color:transparent;"=
><br></span></p><p style=3D"font-size: 13px; font-family: arial, helvetica,=
 clean, sans-serif; background-color: transparent; font-style: normal; "><s=
pan style=3D"background-color:transparent;">In Ken and I's virtual creature=
 paper, novelty was measured in how different a virtual creature's morpholo=
gy was from others in the population, using a coarse small-dimensional spac=
e of morphologies (e.g. their height and mass). Competition (measured in ho=
w far the organisms could locomote) occurred locally between points near in=
 that low-dimensional morphology space. The idea was that NS+LC would disco=
ver a wide range of functional and yet divergent VCs.</span></p><p style=3D=
"font-size: 13px; font-family: arial, helvetica, clean, sans-serif; backgro=
und-color: transparent; font-style: normal; "><span style=3D"background-col=
or:transparent;"><br></span></p><p style=3D"font-size: 13px; font-family: a=
rial, helvetica, clean, sans-serif; background-color: transparent; font-sty=
le: normal; "><span style=3D"background-color:transparent;">However, instea=
d of a morphology space where the underlying evaluation environment is unif=
orm (e.g. the world any creature is evaluated in is exactly the same), you =
could also have something like you are suggesting, where the evaluation env=
ironment varies over a space (e.g. some environments in one part of the geo=
graphic space could be hilly and others in a different area, flat). </=
span></p><p style=3D"font-size: 13px; font-family: arial, helvetica, clean,=
 sans-serif; background-color: transparent; font-style: normal; "><span sty=
le=3D"background-color:transparent;"><br></span></p><p style=3D"font-size: =
13px; font-family: arial, helvetica, clean, sans-serif; background-color: t=
ransparent; font-style: normal; "><span style=3D"background-color:transpare=
nt;">That is, you could have the space where novelty is measured in be an e=
volvable coordinate that specifies its position within some overall 'geogra=
phy', and that the underlying environment shifts over this geography (I thi=
nk this is what is novel about what you are suggesting). Of course, this ar=
tificial 'geography' wouldn't have to align with how environments shift ove=
r terrestrial geography. For example, you could have a 2D geography where g=
ravity varies across one axis, and friction varies over the other. I'm not =
sure what kinds of critters would evolve in such a system, but probably you=
 would find some interesting things. For example, in low gravity/low fricti=
on, you might find sliding high-jumpers, whereas in high gravity/high frict=
ion, you might find little rolling creatures. You could call it a geographi=
cal space, or maybe more generally, a space of niches.</span></p><p style=
=3D"font-size: 13px; font-family: arial, helvetica, clean, sans-serif; back=
ground-color: transparent; font-style: normal; "><span style=3D"background-=
color:transparent;"><br></span></p><p style=3D"font-size: 13px; font-family=
: arial, helvetica, clean, sans-serif; background-color: transparent; font-=
style: normal; "><span style=3D"background-color:transparent;">What I'm get=
ting at is that there may be many different ways to implement the same unde=
rlying multiobjective concept. In other words, you are trying to encourage =
diversity in one or more axes and pressure to achieve in others. That is, y=
ou can use NSGA-II ala NS+LC or behavioral diversity (and replace behaviora=
l or morphological distance with geographical), or you could modify NEAT's =
speciation mechanism as you suggested, which also balances diversity and pe=
rformance. </span></p><p style=3D"font-size: 13px; font-family: arial,=
 helvetica, clean, sans-serif; background-color: transparent; font-style: n=
ormal; "><span style=3D"background-color:transparent;"><br></span></p><p st=
yle=3D"font-size: 13px; font-family: arial, helvetica, clean, sans-serif; b=
ackground-color: transparent; font-style: normal; "><span style=3D"backgrou=
nd-color:transparent;">One important thing to consider is whether you want =
competition to be global (e.g. everyone competes on the same scale of fitne=
ss) or local (e.g. everyone competes purely relative to other organisms in =
their immediate environment). It might be nice to have this be a setting wi=
thin the system, because depending on your application you might want more =
or less "non-objectiveness," where local competition might bias towards mor=
e non-objectiveness and global competition might focus more on overall fitn=
ess optimization.</span></p><p style=3D"font-size: 13px; font-family: arial=
, helvetica, clean, sans-serif; background-color: transparent; font-style: =
normal; "><span style=3D"background-color:transparent;"><br></span></p><p s=
tyle=3D"font-size: 13px; font-family: arial, helvetica, clean, sans-serif; =
background-color: transparent; font-style: normal; "><span style=3D"backgro=
und-color:transparent;">In any case, I think this direction is very interes=
ting from both a research and SharpNEAT perspective, and I look forward to =
see how your work enfolds. I hope my feedback is helpful, and not merely sc=
attered.</span><br></p><p style=3D"font-size: 13px; font-family: arial, hel=
vetica, clean, sans-serif; background-color: transparent; font-style: norma=
l; "><span style=3D"background-color:transparent;"><br></span></p><p style=
=3D"font-size: 13px; font-family: arial, helvetica, clean, sans-serif; back=
ground-color: transparent; font-style: normal; "><span style=3D"background-=
color:transparent;">Best,</span></p><p style=3D"font-size: 13px; font-famil=
y: arial, helvetica, clean, sans-serif; background-color: transparent; font=
-style: normal; "><span style=3D"background-color:transparent;">Joel</span>=
</p> <div class=3D"ygroups-quoted"><br><br>--- In <a href=3D"mailto:neat@ya=
hoogroups.com">neat@yahoogroups.com</a>, <martin.pyka@...> wrote:<br>=
<br><div>Hi Colin,<br>
<br>
your idea of implementing some kind of location=
 in a 2d space for each agent sounds interesting. <br>
<br>
Just to assure =
that I understand you correct: you are working with objective fitness funct=
ions, not a co-evolution approach where a geo-location might also play an i=
mportant role!?<br>
<br>
You wrote, population density should adjust the fi=
tness. This means, two species cannot share the same area (or don't you use=
 the concept of species)!?<br>
<br>
Do you aim to model something in analog=
y to nature? Then, I don't get the link. In natural systems (which is based=
 on co-evolution and open-ended) the location on earth determines what is t=
he predator and what is the prey, and which environmental properties must b=
e incorporated in the evolutionary development. In the simulation that you =
aim to setup (if I understand you correctly), it seems that you would like =
to use the geo-location to create more diversity for your objective search!=
?<br>
<br>
Best,<br>
Martin<br>

<span class=3D""> --- In <a rel=
=3D"nofollow">neat@yahoogroups.com</a>, Colin Green <colin.green1@...&gt=
; wrote:<br>
><br>
> Hi all,<br>
> <br>
> I'm starting to think=
 about direction for the next SharpNEAT<br>
> iteration. There's been a =
lot of talk recently about novelty search<br>
> versus objective search,=
 and maybe mixtures of the two. I myself<br>
> talked about how in the n=
atural world organisms are separated in both<br>
> behavioural space (i.=
e. novel behaviour is less likely to compete for<br>
> the same resource=
s as existing behaviours) but also geographical<br>
> space, and I think=
 that geographical space is a key factor that is<br>
> missing from NEAT=
 based search currently, and possibly EC as a whole,<br>
> with the cave=
at there may be other research groups with work in that<br>
> area that =
I'm unaware of.<br>
> <br>
> My current plan is to focus on this geog=
raphical space idea for this<br>
> iteration because it is the simplest =
to implement. Dealing with<br>
> behavioural space is potentially more c=
omplicated because how to<br>
> compare behaviour varies across problem =
domains and how you identify<br>
> the key factors to compare is probabl=
y a non-trivial problem. I want<br>
> to try and tackle this at some poi=
nt, but I'm also keen to explore the<br>
> geo-space idea.<br>
> <br>=

> What does this all mean in practical terms?<br>
> <br>
> SharpN=
EAT is a kit of parts that allows you to swap in replacement<br>
> parts=
 such as an alternative genetic representation and/or associated<br>
> g=
enetic operators (recombination, mutation, etc) with minimal impact<br>
&gt=
; on other parts in the kit (in principle anyway). I'm proposing to<br>
&gt=
; provide an alternative evolution algorithm class that replaces NEAT's<br>=

> genome based speciation (which clusters genomes into K clusters in<br=
>
> genetic space), with a geographical space alternative (I'll call it<=
br>
> geo-space for short).<br>
> <br>
> The idea is that we have =
some cartesian/euclidean space (probably a<br>
> square 2D space initial=
ly to keep the code simple, but 3D or 'globe'<br>
> space (2-sphere) are=
 reasonable alternatives). The seed genomes are<br>
> each assigned a ra=
ndom coord in the geo-space and this will be fixed<br>
> for the life of=
 that genome. So we are basically adding a physical<br>
> attribute to t=
he genome such that our population members are probably<br>
> better ref=
erred to as organisms (or agents or population members).<br>
> I'll use =
'agent' because it's easier to type :)<br>
> <br>
> Agent fitness is =
now adjusted by population density at the agent's<br>
> geo-location, th=
is allows really bad agents to survive so long as they<br>
> are in a sp=
arse region of geo-space, thus allowing for some diversity<br>
> of the =
genome pool.<br>
> <br>
> Reproduction - I haven't put much thought i=
nto this but the two<br>
> options I see are to create offspring agents =
near to their parent(s)<br>
> versus randomly scattered. Probably some '=
dispersion' variable will<br>
> define the amount of scattering with 0 b=
eing atop of the parent (or<br>
> between the two?) and 1 being totally =
random. (Question: Is e.g. seed<br>
> scattering in nature gaussian?). C=
learly if agent's are spawned near<br>
> their parent's we would expect =
to see clusters of agent's with similar<br>
> behaviour, and that cluste=
ring will increase population density and<br>
> therefore lower the fitn=
ess of agent's in that cluster. So there is a<br>
> form of fitness shar=
ing going on, but as I say, I haven't really<br>
> thought through the i=
mplications and dynamics of that. But it would be<br>
> interesting to s=
et up, play with and observe what happens.<br>
> <br>
> Factoring in =
behavioural space considerations should be possible at a<br>
> later dat=
e, e.g. fitness at a geo-location is not adjusted down if an<br>
> agent=
 has novel behaviour compared to other agent's at that<br>
> geo-locatio=
n.<br>
> <br>
> As per usual - any thoughts and feedback are welcome.=
<br>
> <br>
> Colin<br>
